text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with cheese straws that's right
these super simple breadsticks are
cheesy easy and crispier than young
jeezy
and believe it or not there's no dough
to make we're going to use frozen puff
pastry for this and it really works
incredibly well so we're going to take
one sheet of the aforementioned frozen
puff pastry dough and I want you to put
it down on a floured cutting board and
just let it thaw enough that you can
unfold it the colder this is the easier
it is to work with so it does not need
to be totally thawed as soon as you can
unfold it unfold it and please do not be
concerned about the two seams I know
they look a little rough and a little
gnarly but they will not be a factor so
the next step once we're unfolded is
we're going to brush something on here
to help the cheese stick and a lot of
people use egg wash for this but I don't
I like olive oil and not just any olive
oil my secret trick here is to use a
little bit of the olive oil that
anchovies are packed in and of course we
jokingly refer to anchovies as Italian
msg and that's just going to add a
little bit extra savoriness a little bit
of saltiness but you could certainly
just use regular olive oil for this so
I'm just going to drizzle on a couple
teaspoons and use my pastry brush to
coat the entire surface alright just
like that and once that's done I'm going
to go ahead and season this up a little
bit I'm going to be pretty
straightforward with a little bit of
salt pepper and cayenne but you could
put all kinds of dried herbs and spices
and curry powders and different peppers
smoked paprika things like that so I'm
just showing you my basic formula and
then you will adapt as I've trained you
to do with all these years of
brainwashing and once you're happy with
the seasoning we're going to go ahead
and start grating on some cheese so I'm
going to use some well aged white
cheddar and some parmesan and you'll
notice I'm using the microplane I want
really finely shredded cheese here so
you really do want to use those aged
pungent harder aged cheese's that's just
going to work much better for this and
it's really hard to give you a
measurement but you want to make sure
the surface is covered and it might look
like that's a ton but it really isn't
because it's so finely shredded so after
I did that generous grating of white
cheddar I followed that up with a
grating of Parmesan cheese of course
you're going to use the real stuff
parmigiano-reggiano how many times have
I told you that like probably 150
literally but long story short you're
going to cover the surface with finely
grated sharp cheese of some type and
then we're going to cover it with
a piece of plastic wrap because we want
to press it into the surface by now our
dough is probably fully thawed so this
step should be very easy I might use the
pan to press it down you can just use
your fingertips and palms totally works
probably even better so I press that in
we're going to remove the plastic and
then we're going to cut these into
strips and the best tool for the job is
a pizza cutter of course you can use a
knife but this just works so much better
so I'm going to cut once down each seam
and then each of those thirds I will cut
into thirds so I'm going to get nine
cheese straws per sheet of puff pastry
and you could certainly cut these
smaller and have thinner crisper cheese
straws that's totally up to you just
keep in mind the bigger the strip's the
more bread like these will be so we're
going to cut those as even as possible
and then we're going to twist so I tend
to start by flipping it over so the
seasoned side is down and then sort of
twist from both ends and ideally you
want that seasoned cheesy side facing
out but to be honest it really doesn't
matter once he's baked they look great
anyway but if you can twist it that way
go for it and really that's all there is
to it and once that's twisted just place
it on a lined baking sheet all right one
more time I like to twist it so it kind
of starts in the middle and that will go
from the center out to the ends twisting
like that and then the tighter you twist
these the denser and crisper they will
be and conversely if you twist these
very loosely you'll have a thicker bread
ear cheese straw so really that's up to
you I kind of like to go down the middle
not super skinny and highly twisted but
not too loose either so that's what mine
look like so once those are all twisted
and placed upon our sheet tray I like to
do one other step which probably is
completely unnecessary but I always do
it anyway I'll take some more parmesan
and do another fine grating over the top
and I know what you're thinking hey most
of what's going on sheet pan you totally
wasted it but I didn't check it out
because the dough is now soft and kind
of sticky I'll give them a little roll
and they're going to pick up all that
extra cheese just like that so that is
an optional step but I like to do it I'm
actually paid by this step and at that
point we're going to place those in a
very well preheated 400 degree oven and
those are going to cook into well
browned and crisp about 20 to 30 minutes
depends on how big you majors but after
about 10 or 15 minutes I do like to pull
them out and turn
I'm over because the side that's down
will get a little crispier so I like to
flip them over I want to pop those back
in for another 10 minutes or so until
they look like this they're going to be
beautifully golden brown all right if
you pick it up by one end and they droop
put it back in they're not done so
that's a great way to test them if you
hold it up by the end they should be
perfectly stiff and these were and those
cheese straws are done now I do like to
transfer these onto a wire rack to cool
them if you leave something like this on
a sheet tray can get a little soggy
underneath as it cools so by
transferring them onto the rack to cool
you won't have to worry about that
happening and did they really truly get
crispy and crunchy or do they just look
crispy and crunchy well you be the judge
oh yeah it's been a while since we did
the old fork drag and then of course I
must make you listen to me bite this by
the way a lot of people call these
cheese sticks which really is a more
accurate name because these don't have a
hole in the middle of them so you really
couldn't use these like a straw in other
words these don't suck I went a long way
for that one but anyway this really is a
super simple and versatile technique
very cool for entertaining so I really
do hope you give these a try head over
to food wishes calm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
you
